data.profileText: a Representative from Massachusetts; born in Boston, Mass., September 2, 1749; graduated from Harvard College in 1774; engaged in business in Leicester, Mass.; moved to Worcester in 1776; member of the Massachusetts state constitutional convention of 1788; appointed clerk of the courts and held that office until 1810, when he resigned to serve in Congress; elected as a Federalist to the Eleventh Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Jabez Upham and served from October 8, 1810, to March 3, 1811; declined to be a candidate for reelection in 1810; Massachusetts state councilor,1815-1818; died in Worcester, Mass., September 2, 1827; interment in Mechanic Street Burying Ground.

note.content: Elected to fill vacancy caused by resignation of Jabez Upham, and took his seat December 13, 1810.

researchRecord.name: In the Dwight Foster Papers, ca. 1757-1884, 8 volumes.
